Where politics meets the press

                James and Lachlan Murdoch on the cover of Hollywood Reporter. | Courtesy Hollywood Reporter

            By 
                    Joe Pompeo

10/21/15 11:12 AM EDT
Lachlan and James Murdoch defended their father, Rupert Murdoch, in the wake of uproar over the 84-year-old media mogul's recent Twitter comment suggesting that Barack Obama is not a "real black president."
"Look, it’s a personal platform for him that he values in terms of being able to communicate, and I try not to get involved," said James in a wide-ranging Q&A with The Hollywood Reporter that is the magazine's cover story this week.
Lachlan said that while "externally people have combined the company with our father’s personal opinions, which are super interesting, or his politics, they’re actually not always the same." 
Lachlan was referring to 21st Century Fox, the entertainment conglomerate where Lachlan and Rupert are executive co-chairmen and James is chief executive officer. 
The Hollywood Reporter sit-down was the brothers' first major interview since being elevated to their top roles at the company several months ago.
On Oct. 7, Rupert tweeted the following endorsement of Ben Carson: "What about a real black president who can properly address the racial divide?" The comment prompted widespread criticism and an apology from Rupert.
Rupert's children are known to be more liberal than their father, though they are not as public about their beliefs as he. James told The Hollywood Reporter: "I can speak for myself — my politics are a private matter. I’ve never spoken about them publicly."
The extent to which James and Lachlan's political leanings may differ from their father's has fueled speculation about what their ascension means for Fox News chief Roger Ailes—arguably a hero in Republican circles—who now reports to them and Rupert jointly.
Lachlan reportedly clashed with Ailes when the former was an executive at News Corp. in the early- to -mid-2000s. That was years before the corporate split in 2013 that removed U.S. television assets like Fox News from News Corp. and put them under the newly minted 21st Century Fox banner.
"We both talk to him all the time," Lachlan said of Ailes, responding to a question about their relationship. "The business he’s built, and the channels he’s built, are terrific. We have a huge regard for him, and he’s done a great job."
 "We have a good relationship with Roger, and it’s been a long one," echoed James. "Certainly, from my perspective, he just signed a new contract and we’re really pleased with that, and we hope he stays for as long as he wants."
Speaking of Fox News, the Brothers Murdoch were asked if they get involved when the network comes to blows with Donald Trump.
"We’ll always support our editors and news producers, and certainly our journalists," said Lachlan. "If someone wants to have a feud with any of them, not just Donald Trump, we’ll always support our really hard-working and decent journalists. Part of our job is to protect them." 
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
description: Rupert's children are known to be more liberal than their father, though they are not as public about their beliefs as he.
title: Murdoch heirs defend father Rupert, profess their love of Ailes
